articles.headline: China Purchases Could Undercut Trump’s Larger Trade Goal
articles.snippet: A trade deal could result in China promising to buy hundreds of billions of dollars of American products. It could further cement Beijing’s role in the economy.
articles.abstract: A trade deal could result in China promising to buy hundreds of billions of dollars of American products. It could further cement Beijing’s role in the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the heart of President Trump’s negotiations with China is a troubling contradiction: The United States wants to use the trade talks to encourage the country to adopt a more market-oriented economy. But a key element of a prospective deal may end up reinforcing the economic power of the Chinese state.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Chinese Dissidents Feel Heat of Beijing’s Wrath. Even in Canada.
articles.snippet: She thought she would be safe in Toronto. Then she began speaking out against the Chinese government and became the victim of a lurid smear campaign.
articles.abstract: She thought she would be safe in Toronto. Then she began speaking out against the Chinese government and became the victim of a lurid smear campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario — Search for Sheng Xue on Google in English and you will find the story of an award-winning writer who left China for Canada after the Tiananmen Square uprising and became one of the world’s leading advocates for Chinese democracy.

articles.headline: Behold the Beefless ‘Impossible Whopper’
articles.snippet: Burger King is introducing a Whopper made with a vegetarian patty from the start-up Impossible Foods. The deal is a big step toward the mainstream for start-ups trying to mimic and replace meat.
articles.abstract: Burger King is introducing a Whopper made with a vegetarian patty from the start-up Impossible Foods. The deal is a big step toward the mainstream for start-ups trying to mimic and replace meat.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Would you like that Whopper with or without beef?
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Matt Edge

articles.headline: Saudi Aramco Is World’s Most Profitable Company, Beating Apple by Far
articles.snippet: Earnings at Saudi Arabia’s giant oil company, at $111 billion last year, far outstripped the profits of giant tech companies or rival oil producers.
articles.abstract: Earnings at Saudi Arabia’s giant oil company, at $111 billion last year, far outstripped the profits of giant tech companies or rival oil producers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The earnings of Saudi Arabia’s giant oil company have long been a mystery, kept under wraps by the country’s government. But on Monday, Saudi Aramco opened its books, revealing that it generated $111.1 billion in net income last year, making it probably the world’s most profitable company by far.

articles.headline: White House Whistle-Blower Tells Congress of Irregularities in Security Clearances
articles.snippet: A manager in the White House’s Personnel Security Office said administration officials granted clearances to at least 25 people whose applications had been denied by career employees.
articles.abstract: A manager in the White House’s Personnel Security Office said administration officials granted clearances to at least 25 people whose applications had been denied by career employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A whistle-blower working inside the White House has told a House committee that senior Trump administration officials granted security clearances to at least 25 individuals whose applications had been denied by career employees for “disqualifying issues” that could put national security at risk, the committee’s Democratic staff said Monday.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Maggie Haberman
